From:
 Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, October 10, 2023 10:00 AM
To:
 Office <
office@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Staff Announcement
 
Good morning, Team – 
 
I wanted to- share with you that 
Emani Richmond
 and 
Dustin Puehler
 have both tendered their resignations from LCW. Emani’s last day with us will be Oct. 16. Dustin’s will be Oct. 13. We are working with Dustin to reserve some of his time for servicing Diligent and supporting LCW on contract.
 
In the almost 2 ½ years that Emani has been with us, she has proven to be a brilliant contributor to the consulting team. As an AC she could be counted on to consistently provide senior consultants and clients with excellent support. Her advocacy for wellness contributed to policy changes here and she is the most pleasant person you can hope to ever meet. As a consultant she performed her role with competence, grace, and charm. She will be missed around here.
 
Dustin’s 6 ½ year here have seen him expertly fulfill many roles with aplomb. He brought a sophistication and professionalism to our multimedia efforts, managing complex audio/video shoots and building our capabilities in elearning customization. Dustin could always be counted on to give you to guide you to the best solution. His desire to wow our clients by doing the extra step or thinking outside of the box was a value add to LCW.
 
We have been working to transition Emani’s work over the past week. We will communicate Dustin’s arrangement later this week.
 
Join me in wishing the two of them the best on the next chapters of their careers.
 
Chuck
 
 
Chuck Adams
 
(He/Him)
Co-CEO and Managing Principal

subject: FW: LCW// CHL  2023-2024 DEI Program Deliverables
body:
Hi Emani,
 
I wanted to send a note to let you know I got pulled into another project today and didn’t have time to do the review I planned on our work together. I will plan to get back to you by Tuesday next week.
 
I appreciate the flexibility. Have a nice weekend!
 
Thanks,
Ann
 
From:
 Ann Odens 
Sent:
 Wednesday, October 11, 2023 12:16 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>; Sarah Nodarse <s.nodarse@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: LCW// CHL 2023-2024 DEI Program Deliverables
 
Hi Emani,
 
Thank you for pulling together details of our planning and sharing the roll-out plan. I will review all materials by Friday afternoon and get back to you with any questions.
 
I’m excited to continue the progress with our staff.
 
Thank you,
Ann
 
 
From:
 Emani Richmond <
e.richmond@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, October 11, 2023 10:10 AM
To:
 Ann Odens <
ann@childrensheartlink.org
>
Cc:
 Sarah Nodarse <
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 LCW// CHL 2023-2024 DEI Program Deliverables
 
Hi Ann, 
 
I hope you are well as the team nears your HUGE fundraising event. After collaborating with the LCW team last week we were able to compile each of the needed Discussion/ Participant guides, eLearning links, and subsequent materials to complete the deliverables for the 2023-2024 DEI programming we have slated for you folks.
 
Please take your time reviewing the materials, my only ask is that you open each link to double check they are exactly what you need and please download and save any file I have sent because the DropBox Transfer links expire after a certain date that I am not able to extend. 
 
This link will direct you to the presentation I walked you through about a week ago. 
https://www.dropbox.com/t/r9yNj289lqigB4Jf
 
The presentation details:
-
        
The DEI Programming we completed last year
-
        
Our deliverables for 2023-2024
-
        
And a rollout schedule
 
Here is the tentative rollout schedule I have organized for CHL. I mention that this timeline is tentative because after you rollout the eLearning internally folks may want a few extra weeks to complete it or continue discussions internally before the next activity is moved forward. 
 
November
Project Kickoff; reminder of DEI activities completed last year (using supporting presentation linked above)
Refresher-Self-Directed eLearning: Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias (IMUB)
Set Intercultural Competence goals 
as individuals and a staff
December
Toolkit: Leader-Led IMUB Discussion Guide
Link to Dropbox Transfer file so you can access the Discussion Guide
https://www.dropbox.com/t/sZVx9WKyFOlw3elU
Toolkit discussion during Monthly All-Staff
January
Self-Directed eLearning: 
Managing with Intercultural Competence 
(20 minutes)
eLearning module to be completed before next All-Staff
February
Facilitated Workshop: 
Understanding Microaggressions 
Workshop (2 hours) 
We will be in contact with you in December about getting this training date on the calendar
March
Debrief learnings from Understanding Microaggressions Workshop
Toolkit: 
Post IDI- Debrief Accountability Plan
Attached to email named ‘Post IDI- Debrief- Accountability Plan…’
April + Ongoing
Discuss progress made towards the Post IDI- Debrief Accountability Plan
IDI Assessment 
as needed for new staff(30 min)
 
eLearning Links:
 
IMUB- Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias – 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=dd5f28b9-f9fe-4b63-9fd1-d5c1e02d1967
 
MIC- Managing with Intercultural Competence – 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=d391aab2-1abf-4696-87da-dff7cef7bbff
 
The links are active until March 31
st
 so your staff can retake them as much as they would like between now and then
When logging in participants will be asked to include their 
email address
 and their 
name
, that is how participation is tracked
You have purchased 20 seats to each eLearning, so once 20 unique users log in the links will no longer be active
You can request a status update from us at any time to track the status of completion for the staff
 
I think that sums up the whole kitchen sink! I look forward to CHL receiving this program over the next few months. 
 
Again, please send any questions my way.
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)
Consultant
LCW

subject: Join SIETAR USA's November 8, 2023 Webinar!
body:
The Art of Icebreakers: How to Engage and Inspire Your Workshop Participants ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
WEBINAR: 
'The Art of Icebreakers: How to Engage and Inspire Your Workshop Participants'
 
 
 
 
 
November 8, 2023 @ 11:30 AM (Eastern)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Icebreakers are a critical component to any training workshop. When conducted properly, they are able to draw participants in, engage them and excite them for what comes next. Icebreakers also serve to provide reflection and a deeper introduction to the content of the workshops. As the holidays approach with the hustle and bustle of the season, let’s convene for some fun and to learn best practices to conduct and debrief icebreakers, especially in a virtual setting. What works, what doesn’t? Come and learn from experienced professionals and share your seasonal traditions and get energized for the holiday season. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Non-member registration 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Member Registration

Subject:
 [EXT] RE: DEI Spotlight on Indigenous People Graphic
 
Hello Amira,
 
Please see the attached.
 
Course Description:
 
Spotlight on Indigenous People in North America
 
Indigenous societies have flourished for thousands of years in the Americas, and their cultural contributions continue to impact modern life across North America. Today, there are over 560 federally recognized Native American tribes in the U.S. and more than 630 First Nation communities in Canada. This session investigates the complicated relationship between Indigenous communities and the government, explores the rich traditions of Indigenous peoples, and shares insight on some of the social issues Indigenous communities face today, so you can begin to understand the experience of your Indigenous talent, clients, and market.
 
 
Objectives
Describe key experiences that affect your Indigenous people colleagues.
Consider strategies for productively working with your Indigenous people, colleagues and communities.
Apply what we’ve learned in the session to promote inclusion at your workplace and connect more effectively with Indigenous clients and markets.
 
Please let me know if you need anything else. 
 
Best,
 
Emani Richmond
(she/her/hers)

Course Description:
 
Spotlight on Indigenous People in North America
 
Indigenous societies have flourished for thousands of years in the Americas, and their cultural contributions continue to impact modern life across North America. Today, there are over 560 federally recognized Native American tribes in the U.S. and more than 630 First Nation communities in Canada. This session investigates the complicated relationship between Indigenous communities and the government, explores the rich traditions of Indigenous peoples, and shares insight on some of the social issues Indigenous communities face today, so you can begin to understand the experience of your Indigenous talent, clients, and market.
 
 
Objectives
Describe key experiences that affect your Indigenous people colleagues.
Consider strategies for productively working with your Indigenous people, colleagues and communities.
Apply what we’ve learned in the session to promote inclusion at your workplace and connect more effectively with Indigenous clients and markets.

subject: Can this supplement help you sleep?
body:
TikTok's latest obsession, ashwagandha, is credited with improving sleep and reducing stress.
View this email in your browser.
 
Presented by CVS Health
Does ashwagandha really help with sleep?
October 12, 2023
 
If social media had its way, your medicine cabinet would be overflowing with supplements. TikTok’s latest must-have: ashwagandha. The herb is credited with 
boosting energy and focus
, improving 
sleep
, and reducing stress. Research says it may live up to some of the hype.
 
What is ashwagandha?
A mainstay of Ayurvedic medicine—an ancient Indian holistic healing system—ashwagandha is made from a shrub found in India and Africa that is formulated into teas, powders, and capsules. Ashwagandha is considered an adaptogen—a plant substance that helps regulate cortisol, which, in turn, can reduce the body’s stress response. 
What are the benefits?
The most solid research around ashwagandha shows that it can reduce your body's stress response, help ease anxiety, and 
improve brain function
.
 
Does ashwagandha improve sleep?
Despite how commonly the supplement is used for sleep, there’s not a lot of evidence to show that it helps. A study of just 50 adults found that taking ashwagandha every day for 12 weeks improved sleep. Another 2019 study found that a twice-daily dose of ashwagandha led to a reduction in anxiety and improved sleep. 
If stress or mild anxiety is getting in between you and sleep, ashwagandha could be helpful in reducing anxiety, which may facilitate a better night’s rest—at least according to this limited research.
How much ashwagandha is safe to take?
Up to about 500 milligrams per day is considered safe for most adults, according to the Cleveland Clinic, but the dosage depends on what form you’re taking it in and what you’re taking it for. As with all supplements, it’s best to check with your doctor, who can help you sidestep potential drug interactions, and recommend the right dose or an alternative.
What are the side effects of ashwagandha?
 
Though ashwagandha is generally safe for most adults, according the NIH, it can cause side effects including diarrhea, drowsiness, headache, and upset stomach.
 
Some people can have liver problems when taking ashwagandha, especially if they’re taking it with other medications metabolized in the liver. Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding should avoid taking ashwagandha.
 
Should you take a supplement for sleep?
Dr. Jennifer Martin, a psychologist and immediate past president of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine does not recommend taking ashwagandha or any supplements for sleep issues. Instead, she says, people should get their 
sleep hygiene
 in order. 
Good sleep hygiene means ensuring your bedroom is dark, quiet, and 
cool
; going to bed and waking up around the same time; cutting back on exposure to bright light before bed, and  reducing stress that may be affecting your sleep.
  
Read the full article 
here
.

subject: Well+Being: Hope fatigue, a medical mystery and coffee
body:
A simple routine for more youthful skin 
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  
 
 
 
PUBLISHED BY
READ ONLINE
 | 
SIGN UP
 
Expert advice to help you live well every day. 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
 
 
Tara Parker-Pope 
Happy Thursday. This week we’re writing about a medical mystery, impostor syndrome and coffee metabolism, and we’ve got our weekly “joy” snack. But before that …
This week’s must-reads:
Was it wedding jitters that were making her sick?
 Read our newest 
Medical Mystery.
Are you suffering from impostor syndrome? 
Here’s advice on
 
overcoming it.
California isn’t banning Skittles.
 But what is known as the “Skittles ban” does target 
four additives.
What’s your coffee metabolism?
 Why some people can drink coffee 
all day long.
Mary Lou Retton has severe pneumonia.
 Here’s what 
to know.
How to cope when there’s so much bad news
Earlier this week, I woke up feeling rested and well, with my dog quietly snoozing beside me. I felt ready to start my day.
ADVERTISEMENT
 
 
 
 
And then, I remembered. The headlines and devastating videos from the war between Israel and Gaza surfaced in my mind. The earthquake in Afghanistan. The war in Ukraine. My momentary lightness disappeared, and the anxiety of it all returned to my gut, welled up in my chest and forced my eyes shut again. I hugged my dog, wishing for a better world.
Psychologist Lesley Alderman says her patients have consistently told her they have grown weary of bad news. They have wanted to feel like life would return to normal after years of pandemic living, only to conclude that “normal” isn’t what it used to be.
Alderman has noticed that her patients are experiencing a “deficit of optimism,” feeling overwhelmed and anxious about important issues far beyond their control. She called it “hope fatigue,” and the symptoms include feeling anxious, a need to tune out or feeling like giving up.
Alderman notes that dwelling on issues that seem unfixable can lead to an “anxious paralysis,” but she says there is hope. She outlines eight steps to help ease your anxiety when world events — or even personal ones — are out of your control.
Take a break from the news. 
“I advise patients who are feeling depressed by the headlines to read the news just once a day, turn off alerts on their phone and, if possible, check social media sparingly.”
Take care of yourself.
 “I tell my patients: You have to be in good fighting shape to cope with the current turbulence.” That means boosting your resilience by sleeping, eating and exercising well and engaging in life-affirming activities.
Focus on the present. 
Get in the habit of anchoring yourself in the here and now. Fretting about the future is not helpful.
Try a breathing exercise.
 Take a few deep breaths. Inhale to the count of five and exhale to the count of five. It will help calm your sympathetic nervous system (the fight-or-flight response) and lower your anxiety.
Think about your victories. 
Remind yourself of what’s working well in your life — whether it’s your job, friendships or something else.
Be your own therapist.
 Ask yourself, “What do I specifically feel hopeless about and why?” Being able to put into words what’s getting you down can help you feel less flooded by emotions and better able to process the information rationally.
Take action. 
Worrying doesn’t help one’s mental health, but taking action does.
Join forces with a friend. 
Pick a cause. There are hundreds of nonprofits dedicated to addressing some of the most tenacious challenges on the planet. Donate money or volunteer.
These steps won’t ease the suffering of others or solve a geopolitical crisis or end a war. But they will help you manage your anxiety, be more present for yourself and others and, hopefully, take action to make your community better.
“Look around your community,” Alderman writes. “Maybe your local playground would benefit from a basketball court, or your church or synagogue could sponsor a refugee family. When people engage in local issues, they have a renewed sense of optimism.”
Read more about hope fatigue and what you can do about it.
 
(Celia Jacobs for The Washington Post)
Advice
 
8 ways to feel less anxious about things beyond your control
How to feel less anxious and hopeless about climate change, the war in Ukraine and other things beyond your control.
By Lesley Alderman, LCSW
Read more
 
 
 
(Abbey Lossing for The Washington Post)
How much sunshine are you getting?
One simple thing we can do for both mental and physical health is spend a little time outdoors in the sunshine. In many places, fall is one of the best seasons for spending time outdoors — there’s plenty of sunshine, mild temperatures and gorgeous fall foliage.
The typical person is outside for far fewer hours in the day than was the case generations ago, said Richard Weller, a professor of dermatology at the University of Edinburgh.
“Until the Industrial Revolution, 150 years ago, we have lived our entire evolutionary history outdoors all day, every day,” he said. “What is abnormal is that we now spend our lives inside and briefly pop outside.”
But exposure to daylight has been shown to help boost the body’s production of vitamin D, mitigate digital eyestrain, regulate a person’s circadian rhythm and increase alertness and mood.
Stepping outside in the morning, within the first few hours after waking up, is the most important signal you can send to your body’s circadian clock. Depending on what time you have to get to work, the timing of a sunny morning walk may not be possible, but there’s always the weekend.
Sunshine has been in the news lately because many Apple watches that count our steps and check our heart rates can now keep track of our sunlight exposure. To learn more, read the full report.
 
(Washington Post Illustration; iStock)
How much sunshine are you getting? Now your watch can keep track.
Daylight exposure has been shown to boost alertness, mood and the body’s production of vitamin D, mitigate eye strain and regulate a person’s circadian rhythm.
By Teddy Amenabar
Read more
 
 
A simple routine for more youthful skin
This week a reader is looking for a simple, affordable prescription that will help keep skin more youthful. Our Ask a Doctor columnist, Trisha S. Pasricha, did a deep dive into the medical research on skin care and came up with a surprising, simple morning and evening routine. You can read about it here.
And use our 
Ask a Doctor form
 to submit a question, and we may answer it in a future column.
 
(Washington Post illustration; iStock)
Advice
 
The simple, science-backed routine for more youthful skin
No matter your age, taking care of your skin doesn’t have to be expensive.
By Trisha Pasricha, MD
Read more
 
 
Find your joy snack!
Here are a few things that brought us joy this week.
We can’t stop thinking about these crispy potatoes with a creamy chimichurri sauce that starts with parsley and cashews. 
Watch this TikTok video
 and then go straight to your kitchen.
The Voraciously team is celebrating National Book Month by 
pairing great books with great food
. There’s key lime pie to enjoy with Nora Ephron’s “Heartburn.” Or enjoy a mint julep while reading “The Great Gatsby.” Call your book club friends and enjoy one of these nine recipes inspired by great literary meals.
This record-setting 2,749 pound pumpkin is 
named Michael Jordan.
It was the year of the sow! The ladies dominated Fat Bear Week this year. 
Meet the winner: Grazer
. She’s got blonde ears, a bodacious bod and a reputation for being a warrior mother, writes our fat-bear expert, Natalie B. Compton. You’ll love Natalie’s report and an accompanying YouTube video of Grazer in action.
And if you haven’t gotten enough fat-bear news, here’s one of my 
favorite Your Move columns
. Gretchen Reynolds explores the science of the beachball-shaped bruins and how understanding their hibernation can help us learn more about diabetes, muscle atrophy and inactivity.
Want to know more about “joy” snacks? Our Brain Matters columnist 
Richard Sima explains.
 
Y
ou can also 
read this story as a comic
.
Please let us know how we are doing. Email me at 
wellbeing@washpost.com
. You can also 
find us on TikTok.

 Wednesday, October 11, 2023 10:46 PM
To:
 Emani Richmond <e.richmond@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Carta Session
 
Dear Emani
 
I wrote a message directed to you and Leslie. Please let me know if you think we should forward it to her.
 
This session was literally the worst training I have ever delivered because I had prepared the material for a different audience. 
The way to present about cultural differences in a session with mixed audience is comparing cultures, with no focus in any.
 
For me, the worst thing was not the questioning, because if you present about a subject that your audience feels their expertise on the subject equals yours, you should expect questioning.
 
The worst was to feel the audience believed I was offering munition to the American team to attack them. At some point, discussing racism with a high middle class white audience, I was so uncomfortable that I lost what I was saying and repeated myself like crazy. 
 
I would like to send this also to Randall and Rebecca, because I wouldn´t like them to hear about it from somebody else, but first I would like to hear your opinion.
 
Best
Lucy

Subject:
 2023 DEI Summit & LCW- mtg. w/ Ozakh 
 
We can talk about the conference, our background + case studies
 
Audience: 350 people, this is what we are seeing, we are known for our clients, we create all of our trainings in house we can deliver it in any language
Who is attending which companies: broad ( a lot of ATL representation, many different HQs (Insight Global will be hosting them at their HQ)
Higer Ed, folks in non-profits, Tech firms Black Bod, Delta (Sponsor) VA Tech, City representations, Google, North Western Mutual, Ulta and most of them have a leadership role within DEI and their organizations
 
Introductions 
Trying to find ways to engage w/ each other and bring in the lightness fun and innocence with people 
I managed Girls Inc. of Chicago, eliciting that youthfulness and susceptibility for leading
AK- I grew up in Chicago, a lot 
 
We work w/ leaders and managers understand culture and how do we succeed across cultures, being w/ companies as they are going throughout their changes, we have worked with companies that have had success
Our examples can span different parts of the market
This is less than a month away, what day would you like our assistance, we bring our own differences to the conference, we are trying to get Brand Awareness
Mining conference and we hosted panels from that perspective 
 
It’s not only helping companies and it’s also helping people get better understandings of each other
Chicago Chamber of Commerce, I know Chicago so we know she’s here
Family is Pakastani, born in in Dubai, in Memphis TN, works at the National Civil Rights Museum
Was managing program for Girls Inc, presenting at trauma-informed approach to learning and how to work w/ other people and a position came up at the National Civil Rights Museum and will focus on community engagement
 
Corporate Equity center & the museum, develops programming in the historic aspects of the community and that relates to the basis of the programming at the museum creating the through line of the history of slavey and oppression how does that relate to communities and systems now and where are some of these inequities rooted 
And I attended the DEI Summit last year and I learned a lot and I’m excited to be on the planning committee
Sounds like you have a good understanding of what this ask is
 
30-45 min of facilitated time | Nov 2
nd
 & 10:15 am EST
Can talk through case studies and the way we work w/ groups
Data or results from the work that you have done
We are implementing these sessions b/c “can we spend more time learning together “
People are engaging w/ each other and how we can uniquely support them through that challenge
Around culture and how wen can elevate our brand to be an equitable space to work
We love examples that you have w/ case studies it’s an opportunity where you grab people a
SCI model this is why… through the process of having interactions and adding metrics
Case study of learning journeys and their impact in the companies that experienced them… 
How the engagement started 
How the engagement was funded and sustained 
Challenges we encountered …
Examples to use ARCH program, J&J work, Heritage programming 
***What are the 3 top takeaways that will be in the session 
We delivered on the SCI model… 
Last year the summit’s focus was on data and how do we translate data to cultural shifts and we can speak to this and lead folks through this 
Folks love tools they can take away from this experience and we can potentially work long-teem w/ them 
Depending on what role you would like for us to play we can play that role 
 
What would success look like in the conference so we can build our content to support the content
Theme: We are resilient,  
We understand the challenges associated with DEI work how exhausting that can be to defending Equity when people don’t believe it’s necessary, we hope people leave the conference w/ a greater sense of community and have more tools in their toolbelt 
How do we restore ourselves wellness, knowledge and skills what can folks take away w/ them to move forward in the work when there’s so many things working against them 
 
Training before this session: 
The journey to Belonging
What does it mean to belong, and then we come in w/ the tools for how to get to that end state 
 
Action Items:
Us to receive the agenda 
Send Lori an outline of what the presentation will look like
Can send cell in the chat and I feel like what you deliver will be phenomenal …
Will send the form for speakers to complete (for , room for headshot + bios will ask that you share some takeaways like walk up music
Will allow us to se hotels that are blocks at (Hyatt Place $129/ night)
